coredata.dc:title: Oxygen vacancies in Bi2Sn2O7 quantum dots to trigger efficient photocatalytic nitrogen reduction
coredata.dc:creator: Zhang, Yi
Di, Jun
Qian, Xu
Ji, Mengxia
Tian, Ziqi
Ye, Liqun

Yin, Sheng
Li, Huaming
Xia, Jiexiang
coredata.dc:description: Constructing highly efficient ultra-small nanomaterials to achieve nitrogen reduction without sacrificing reagents or additional photosensitizers is still challenging. Herein, one-step solvothermal method was used to tune Bi2Sn2O7 to the quantum dots (QDs), so as to tune the active sites on the surface and achieve the optimization of the energy band structure. Benefiting from quantum size effect and electron back-donation mechanism of surface oxygen vacancies, the improved charge migration and optimized molecular nitrogen activation in Bi2Sn2O7 QDs can be achieved, triggering excellent photocatalytic nitrogen fixation behavior. The ammonia generation rate over Bi2Sn2O7 QDs is up to 334.8 µmol g−1 h−1 in pure water, 12.2 times higher than the bulk counterpart. The density functional theory revealed that the rate-limiting step energy barrier during the nitrogen fixation reaction can be lowered by oxygen vacancy engineering. This work would provide new insights into the synthesis of defect-state quantum dots and nitrogen photoreduction reactions.

Photocatalyst

Characterization and theoretical prediction of oxygen vacancies in Bi2Sn2O7 QDs
Research on the performance and mechanism of photocatalytic nitrogen reduction

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a, b) TEM; (c, d) high-resolution TEM; (e, f) atomic-resolution STEM-HAADF images of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs.

(a) XRD; (b) Raman spectra; (c) fitted XPS O 1s spectra; (d) EPR spectra; (e) UV–vis DRS curves of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 QDs; (f) the density of states (DOS) curves of Bi sites in the perfect crystal and those models containing one and two vacancies in each cell (labeled as −1OV and −2OV, respectively).

Quantitative determination of the generated NH3 (a) under light irradiation; (b) under different gas and light conditions; (c) transient photocurrent response; (d) time-resolved transient PL decay of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 QDs; (e) DRIFT spectra of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs; (f) NH3 TPD spectra of prepared samples.

(a) The free-energy diagram of NRR process on perfect Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7-OV surface; the top view of the most stable structure of (b) perfect Bi2Sn2O7 and (c) Bi2Sn2O7 surface containing oxygen vacancy.

head.ce:title: Oxygen vacancies in Bi2Sn2O7 quantum dots to trigger efficient photocatalytic nitrogen reduction

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Constructing highly efficient ultra-small nanomaterials to achieve nitrogen reduction without sacrificing reagents or additional photosensitizers is still challenging. Herein, one-step solvothermal method was used to tune Bi2Sn2O7 to the quantum dots (QDs), so as to tune the active sites on the surface and achieve the optimization of the energy band structure. Benefiting from quantum size effect and electron back-donation mechanism of surface oxygen vacancies, the improved charge migration and optimized molecular nitrogen activation in Bi2Sn2O7 QDs can be achieved, triggering excellent photocatalytic nitrogen fixation behavior. The ammonia generation rate over Bi2Sn2O7 QDs is up to 334.8 µmol g−1 h−1 in pure water, 12.2 times higher than the bulk counterpart. The density functional theory revealed that the rate-limiting step energy barrier during the nitrogen fixation reaction can be lowered by oxygen vacancy engineering. This work would provide new insights into the synthesis of defect-state quantum dots and nitrogen photoreduction reactions.
In pure water, the photo-generated electron enriched in the oxygen vacancies of Bi2Sn2O7 quantum dots trigger the photocatalytic nitrogen fixation reaction.

ce:section.ce:para: Ammonia (NH3) plays a crucial role in the modern agricultural and production industries, also there is a broad prospect for the realization of ammonia-air fuel cells as a new energy source in the future [1–3]. The process of converting free nitrogen to combined nitrogen is arduous, mainly due to the difficulty of breaking the stable NN triple bond in nitrogen (bond energy: 940.95 kJ mol−1) [4]. For the time being, the nitrogen fixation process is mainly achieved through these ways: lightning in nature, biological nitrogen fixation and Haber–Bösch process. However, there are still disadvantages such as difficult control, long cycle, high energy consumption and pollution [5–7]. In recent years, many new approaches to implement nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) have arisen, such as photocatalysis [8–10], electrocatalysis [11–13] and photoelectrocatalysis methods [14]. Especially, photocatalytic nitrogen fixation process requires only solar energy as driving force in water, own potential economic value and important scientific significance [15].

For NRR, the surface oxygen vacancies of the material have the function to capture and activate nitrogen [16]. Due to the presence of oxygen vacancies, the surface will be enriched with localized electrons. As such, the electron-donating nature of localized electrons around oxygen vacancies can activate inert adsorbed nitrogen molecules via π-back-donation, spitting the nitrogen-nitrogen triple bond and achieve the conversion to ammonia [17]. Therefore, the design and construction of oxygen vacancies as well as the realization of concentration control would promote the improvement of nitrogen fixation performance [18].

Among numerous photocatalysts, Pyrochlore Bi2Sn2O7, as an ordered fluorite structure oxide, possesses small oxygen atom work function, which has potential ability for photochemical nitrogen fixation [19]. The SnO6 octahedral structure in the Bi2Sn2O7 unit cell is composed of a Sn atom coordinated with six O atoms, linked by a common apex [20]. This common vertex space structure, which facilitates the transmission and separation of photogenerated carriers, can improve the charge separation efficiency. As a ternary A/B/O compound, the orbit is highly dispersed, the valence band maximum and the conduction band minimum of this material are mainly composed of Bi3+ with a hybrid state of 5d106s26p0, Sn4+ of 4d105s05p0, and 2p O. Based on this, the energy band structure could be optimized by adjusting the concentration of oxygen, so that photogenerated electrons would be more easily excited and transferred to the catalyst surface to participate in the reaction [21].

Therefore, Bi2Sn2O7 is expected to be designed to a quantum size so that more oxygen vacancies in the structure can be exposed on the surface. Upon reaching the atomic level, due to quantum confinement effects, surface effects, dielectric confinement effects, etc., the color, photochemical properties, and electrochemical properties of the materials would become rather different [22–25]. As the particle size of quantum dots decreases, most of the atoms are likely to be exposed on the surface, resulting in insufficient coordination of the surface atoms. At the same time, the movement of internal electrons in all directions is restricted, which is easy to form trapped electrons or holes, enabling the surface to realize high activity [26,27].

In this work, Bi2Sn2O7 has been explored for photocatalytic nitrogen fixation for the first time. By decreasing the size of Bi2Sn2O7 to quantum dots, abundant oxygen vacancies can be engineered into Bi2Sn2O7, thereby improving the efficient separation of charges and N2 adsorption. Meanwhile, the existence of oxygen vacancies favors the exposure of surrounding Bi atoms, which work as the active site, resulting in more low coordinated active Bi atoms to bond with intermediates. As a result, the optimized molecular nitrogen activation and efficient charge separation can be realized in Bi2Sn2O7 QDs, endowing it with greatly improved photocatalytic nitrogen fixation behavior than bulk counterpart.
All chemicals were in analytical grade and obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co.

0.5 mmol Bi2O3 with 1 mmol SnO2 were uniformly dispersed in ethanol solution under stirring, evaporated to dryness, then transferred to porcelain boat, and finally calcined in a muffle furnace at 750 °C for 24 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min.

1 mmol of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O with 0.3 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) were added to 15 mL of mannitol (0.1 M), ultrasonically dispersed, designated as solution A. 1 mmol of Na2SnO4·4H2O was dissolved in 5 mL of mannitol, as solution B. Under vigorous stirring, the solution B was slowly dropped into the solution A with a dropper. After 30 min, the pH of the mixture was adjusted to 12 by NaOH (2 M), stirring for 30 min. Finally, it was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave at 200 °C for 24 h, as heating rate of 5 °C/min.

The elemental composition and crystal structure of the samples were verified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer). Laser Raman Spectrometer (American ThermoFisher DXR) was applied to analysis molecular structure. The transmissive topography and size structure of the materials were visually presented through transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F) and aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy at high-angular annular dark field operated at 80 kV (STEM-HAADF, JEM-ARM200F). The elemental composition and surface binding energy of the obtained sample were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, VG MultiLab 2000 system). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum was utilized using a Bruker ESR JES-FA200 spectrometer at 77 K. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) was obtained to research the photochemical properties of that as prepared samples across a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-2450). The electrochemical properties of nanomaterials were studied by electrochemical workstations. The nitrogen source was measured by isotope experiment using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer (BRUKER AVANCEⅡ 400 MHz). Liquid to solid contact angle was calculated by contact angle measuring instrument (Attention, KSV CM200).

5 mg as-prepared sample was dissolved in 1 mL ethylene glycol to produce a suspension. Then 20 µL of the prepared sample paste was smeared onto ITO glass plate within an area of 0.5 cm2. The photoelectric response properties were explored through a three-electrode system (platinum wire was worked as counter electrode, Ag/AgCl/KCl as reference electrode). The phosphate buffer solution (PBS) (0.1 M, pH 7.0, 0.1 M KCl), 5 mM Fe(CN)6 3−/Fe(CN)6 4− were prepared for the analysis of photocurrent and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS).

Under standard atmospheric pressure, a 100 mL quartz bottle with external circulating water was used as a reaction vessel, and the 300 W Xe lamp was used as light source. In the experimental procedure, 50 mg of the prepared sample was dispersed in 100 mL deionized water. Notably, the reaction temperature was maintained at 25° by externally circulating water. Before turning on the lights, the solution was passed through N2 (purity ≥ 99.999%) in the dark and bubbled for 30 min to establish an adsorption-desorption equilibrium. Meanwhile, high purity Ar (purity ≥ 99.999%) was substituted for the control experiment and bubbled for 12 h in the dark to remove most of the dissolved nitrogen in the water. During the photocatalytic reaction, about 8 mL of the suspension was taken from the reaction flask every 20 min for subsequent nitrogen fixation performance analysis.

The nitrogen fixation amount was analyzed by the Nessler reagent method. Before the experiment, different ratios of ammonia nitrogen standard working solution were prepared, then potassium sodium tartrate solution and Nessler reagent were added, mixed and allowed to stand for a period of time to produce a color reaction. A standard curve was established by measuring the sample absorption using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer (UV-2450, Shimadzu) at λ = 420 nm using water as a reference solution. During the experiment, a certain amount of the supernatant was filtered through a 0.22 µm membrane filter after centrifugation, then transferred to a 5 mL colorimetric tube and diluted with water to a specific ratio. Finally, the absorption of the sample was measured and the concentration of the combined nitrogen was calculated through the standard curve.

The sample was placed in the reaction cell and pressed to keep the surface flat, then sealed and purged with argon to remove surface impurities. After the sample reached adsorption equilibrium under N2 atmosphere, light up the Xenon lamp to illuminate the sample and then record per 10 min.

The isotope experiment was used to further verify the nitrogen source, 50 mg of the catalyst with 50 mL of deionized water were placed in a closed vessel and evacuated to a vacuum, then 14N2 and 15N2 were passed to achieve different gas components. The reaction was continuously illuminated with the Xe lamp. 0.22 nm filter was applied to remove the suspension impurities in the reaction solution, 1 mL of the clarifying liquid was removed to mix with 200 µL of HCl, finally placed in a nuclear magnetic tube for 1H NMR spectroscopy.

The sample was heated under Ar gas to remove the surface impurities. The target gas (N2 or NH3) was introduced to reach the adsorption equilibrium and then the temperature was programmed under Ar atmosphere to study the ability of N2 or NH3 desorption, the temperature range was from room temperature to 700 °C, and the rate was 5 °C/min.

All the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed by using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) to investigate the NRR process on Bi2Sn2O7. The exchange-correlation energy was treated by adopting the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). Projector augmented wave (PAW) methods were employed for the pseudopotentials. Gaussian smearing method was applied with smearing width of 0.05 eV. Spin polarization was also considered. The energy cutoff for the plane wave was set to be 450 eV and the convergence criterion of geometry relaxation was 0.03 eV/Å in force. The typical (001) facet with exposed Bi site was cut to build simulation model that contains four layers of Bi atoms. To avoid the interaction between periodic structures, a 15 Å vacuum layer was added in the z-direction. The size of simulation box is 15.255 Å × 13.211 Å × 25.853 Å. The DFT-D3 method was used to consider the van der Waals interaction. The Brillouin zone was sampled with the 1 × 1 × 1 and 7 × 7 × 1 k-point grids for geometry relaxation and electronic structure calculation, respectively. The Gibbs free energy change in each hydrogenation step was calculated according to the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model proposed by Nørskov and co-workers, expressed as:
△ G =
△ E
DFT
+
△ E
ZPE
− T Δ S
where ΔE DFT is the DFT energy difference, and the ΔE ZPE and ΔS were yielded from vibration analysis. T is the temperature.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Micromorphology of oxygen-vacancy-rich Bi2Sn2O7 constructed by quantum size strategy
ce:section.ce:para: Pyrochlore Bi2Sn2O7 was adjusted to quantum size by PVP assisted solvothermal process so that more low-coordinated surface atoms can be exposed and been lost to form vacancies. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to visually analyze the structure and surface morphology of the sample. Compared with the bulk Bi2Sn2O7 (Fig. S1), the Bi2Sn2O7 QDs ( Fig. 1a–d) appeared as a uniformly dispersed nano-resolution structure in quantum dot size below 10 nm, and the lattice spacing was 0.309 nm, indicating the dominant growth of the crystal on the (024) crystal plane. Each element exhibited homogeneous distribution (Fig. S2). The atomic structure of representative Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was further studied by aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy with high-angle annular dark field imaging technique (STEM-HAADF), the lattice spacing in the sample was 0.268 and 0.338 nm, corresponded to (028), (−1−15) crystallographic plane respectively. According to the unit cell parameters (α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, a = 7.58033 Å, b = 7.58033 Å, c = 37.1321 Å) [28], the angle between the two crystal planes in the triclinic system was calculated as 68.11º, consistent with Fig. 1e, f shown. From atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Fig. S3a, b), the Bi2Sn2O7 QDS exhibited a uniform circular shape with a thickness of less than 8 nm, conforming that the material was on the order of nanometers in all three dimensions, matched with the TEM analysis.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Characterization and theoretical prediction of oxygen vacancies in Bi2Sn2O7 QDs
ce:section.ce:para: X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) suggested the successful synthesis of Bi2Sn2O7. As shown in Fig. 2a, the peaks of 2-Theta at 28.85°, 33.43°, 48.01°, 57.98° were corresponded to (024), (028), (220) and (−2−212) crystal planes (JCPDS No. 96-432-6954). Compared with bulk Bi2Sn2O7, the peak shape of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was wider and lower, which was caused by the broadening of the diffraction peak due to the reduction of grain size. Raman spectra (Fig. 2b) of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 QDs showed great differences due to the influence of quantum confinement effect and surface effect. As the crystal size decreased, the spectrum of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs turned into wider and the half-width decreased [18]. The peak of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was changed from 73°, 92° to 68° and 89°. Such an asymmetric blue shift related to its defect state, implied that some atoms on the surface lacked adjacent atoms, so that the surface stress of the crystal was weakened. XPS was applied to further analyze the chemical state of elements (Figs. 2c, S4). For Bi 4f, the weakness peaks at 162.0 and 156.3 eV were corresponded to a low-valence Bi around with oxygen vacancies. Binding energy at 529.3, 530.2 and 531.5 eV in XPS O1s were ascribed to the oxygen in Bi-O-Bi, the low-oxide oxygen surrounded by a large number of oxygen vacancies and adsorbed oxygen molecules, respectively [18,29]. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was further used to verify the presence of oxygen vacancies. In Fig. 2d, the signal response at g = 2.001 of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was much stronger, in that the surface effects of quantum dots changed atomic coordination and electron spin conformation, confirming more oxygen vacancies were exposed on the surface of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs. The optical property analysis results were given by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (Fig. 2e). Due to the effect of oxygen vacancies, surface free electrons exhibited a special plasmon resonance mode, meanwhile, the sample gained stronger absorption characteristics with darker color. The Tauc plots (Fig. S5) showed that the valence bands of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs were reduced to 2.0 eV, calculated by the formula αhν = A(hν − Eg)n/2. XPS analysis obtained the valence band of the material (Fig. S6), the VB of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 QDs were 1.78 and 0.71 eV, and the conduction band (CB) can be calculated as −0.76 and −1.29 eV, respectively. Furthermore, the effect of oxygen vacancy on the electronic structure was investigated through density-functional-theory (DFT), as shown in Fig. 2f. As the concentration of oxygen vacancy in Bi2Sn2O7 increases, more valence electrons of Bi atom close to vacancy are filled into the conduction band. Herein, the Fermi level moves upwards and the band gap gradually decreases. As a result, the charge transfer from the catalyst to N2 as well as the catalytic performance would be significantly promoted.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Research on the performance and mechanism of photocatalytic nitrogen reduction
ce:section.ce:para: The nitrogen fixation performance of the sample was determined by the activity test ( Fig. 3a). After 60 min Xe lamp illumination, the ammonia amount of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 was 13.7 µmol/L, and the Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was 167.4 µmol/L (corresponded to 334.8 µmol g−1 h−1). Benefited from the quantum size and abundant oxygen vacancies, the Bi2Sn2O7 QDs displayed 12.2 times increased activity for NH3 formation relative to bulk Bi2Sn2O7. Compared to other reported photocatalysts (Table S1), the quantum dot material still exhibited outstanding performance [30–43]. By using a 420 nm filter, the resulting source range was simulated in the visible range, and the performance of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs and bulk Bi2Sn2O7 was reduced to 58.2 and 2.92 µmol/L, respectively, indicating that the sample had a good response to UV light. After reaction, Bi2Sn2O7 QDs still kept the initial crystal structure (Fig. S7), and maintained the catalytic efficiency of 78% under 5 cycles of 1 h reaction process (Fig. S8). Through the control experiment to explore the factors affecting nitrogen fixation (Fig. 3b), the ammonia production of Bi2Sn2O7 was 1.5 µmol/L under Ar atmosphere, which was mainly caused by dissolved nitrogen in water and nitrogen adsorption on the surface of the sample. The isotope labeling experiment (Fig. S9) was employed to verify the source of nitrogen. The 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) of the 14NH4Cl and 15NH4Cl standards corresponded to the triplets and doublets, respectively. Under pure 14N2, the signal of Bi2Sn2O7 QDS only enhanced at the corresponding triplets, while in the mixed atmosphere (50% 15N2, 50% 14N2), a new signal appeared at the corresponding doublets position, confirming that the raw material of activation reaction was derived from exogenous nitrogen.

To gain insight into the origin of the higher NH3 generation rate, the interfacial adsorption, charge separation, and product desorption process were studied. Firstly, the separation and migration behavior of photogenerated charge were explored. Transient photocurrent response (Fig. 3c) with several cycles showed that the intensity of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was five times higher than that of bulk sample, revealing that quantum dots containing oxygen vacancies were more likely to generate free electrons after being excited by light, meanwhile surface defects had a cumulative effect on electrons. The time-resolved transient photoluminescence (PL) spectra (Fig. 3d) were used to study the charge separation and migration processes of materials. Bi2Sn2O7 QDs exhibited a longer electron lifetime. At quantum size, electrons were excited to transition from bulk center to sample surface more effectively, while surface oxygen vacancies formed electron trapping states and served as charge carrier separation center, reduced electron loss by recombination, further increased carrier lifetime, and greatly improved charge separation efficiency [44,45]. The radius of the arc of the Nyquist plots (Fig. S10) of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was smaller, and the radius was further reduced after the illumination, indicating that Bi2Sn2O7 QDs owned better conductivity under illumination, and the oxygen vacancies could effectively reduce the interface resistance, which contributed to the positive migration of photogenerated carriers.

Generally, the adsorption and activation of N2 have a profound effect on the performance of the catalyst. In Fig. S11, the static water contact angles of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 QDs were 57.23° and 6.75°. Due to the quantum size and surface defects, Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was more hydrophilic, so it had more probability to contact with dissolved nitrogen in water. In Fig. S12, compared with the bulk sample, Bi2Sn2O7 QDs showed higher N2 chemisorption peaks, which confirmed that oxygen vacancies lead to a significant increase in the number of active sites for N2 adsorption. The adsorption and activation of nitrogen were studied by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation (DRIFT) during the reaction (Figs. 3e, S13). After dark adsorption equilibrium, multiple peaks showed corresponding changes through the increase of illumination time, and the intensity growth rate of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs is much higher than that of bulk Bi2Sn2O7. Among them, peaks at 1648 cm−1 was corresponded to chemically adsorbed nitrogen, 3748 and 3608 cm−1 were ascribed to OH and ν(NH) stretching vibrations, 2930 and 1416 cm−1 were assigned to NH4 + characteristic absorption peaks. The 1712 and 1557 cm−1 were attributed to NH3 molecular characteristic absorption peaks. Specifically, due to the electron back-donation phenomenon [46], electrons were donated to the anti-bond orbitals in the gas molecules, weakening NN bond energy, further forming intermediates and gradually reducing it to a combined state. Finally, in Fig. 3f, the desorption diffusion process of NH3 from the surface was explored by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3 TPD). The initial desorption temperature of Bi2Sn2O7 QDs was lower and two new peaks appeared after 360 °C, indicating that the construction of oxygen vacancies could make more NH3 more easily released from the surface [47].

To explore the NRR reactivity nature, DFT calculations were performed. The simulation indicates that N2 can hardly be adsorbed on the perfect Bi2Sn2O7 surface unless oxygen vacancy is created. The system containing oxygen vacancy is labeled as Bi2Sn2O7-Ov. Previous studies have demonstrated that the distal pathway is a favorable mechanism rather than the alternative pathway for the associative nitrogen reduction on Bi-containing system [48–50]. As shown in Fig. 4, the protonation of N2 to form *NNH is the potential-determining step for the whole NRR process, similar to other reported systems. The formation of *NNH requires a free energy uphill of 2.20 eV, which is lower than various Bi-containing systems [51]. In free N2 molecule, the bond length is 1.09 Å, indicating a strong triple bond. While after being activated on the Bi site (Fig. S14), the NN bond length is elongated to 1.22 Å, related to a significantly weakened chemical bond. Simultaneously, a new BiN bond is formed with bond length of 2.49 Å. Most of the subsequent protonation steps from *NNH3 to *N are exothermic. Especially, desorption of the final product NH3 is quite feasible. Bader charge analysis demonstrates that the oxygen vacancy leads to the atomic charge on Bi less positive, from +1.87|e| to +1.33|e|. More valence electrons on Bi promote the interaction between inert nitrogen and the active site.

For this photocatalytic nitrogen fixation system (Fig. S15): By reducing the size of Bi2Sn2O7 to quantum dots to generate a large number of oxygen vacancies, the electronic structure of the material is optimized and the separation efficiency of charges is improved. Also, oxygen vacancies provide a large number of sites for N2 adsorption and expose Bi atoms near the vacancies as active sites. Benefit from the changes in the local electronic density of states caused by oxygen vacancies, the NN triple bond energy could be reduced and form the BiN bond with Bi atoms near the vacancies, thereby stabilizing the intermediate for further hydrogenation to produce NH3. The whole N2 hydrogenation process is distal associative pathway, in which the continuously protonation is performed on the N atom furthest from Bi2Sn2O7 to form a NH3 and then release to leave another N for further continuously hydrogenation. All experimental and theoretical results show that the adjustment of quantum size to expose more oxygen vacancies could effectively promote nitrogen fixation, which opens up new possibilities for the design of photocatalytic applications of defect-state quantum dots.

In summary, Bi2Sn2O7 with abundant oxygen vacancies was controllably produced through adjusting to quantum size. It is the first exploration to employ Bi2Sn2O7 as photocatalyst for nitrogen photofixation. The Bi2Sn2O7 QDs catalyst exhibited high activity under illumination, in which the ammonia production rate reached 334.8 µmol g−1 h−1 without any scavenger. Due to quantum size and oxygen vacancies, Bi2Sn2O7 QDs materials exhibited unique photochemical properties, increased charge separation efficiency and better N2 activation than bulk Bi2Sn2O7, leading to 12.2 time increased activity. This work provided not only a strategy for constructing high-efficiency quantum-scale photocatalysts with abundant oxygen vacancy, but also new avenues toward achieving robust solar-driven N2 conversion process.

Yi Zhang: Conceptualization, Investigation, Data curation, Writing – original draft. Jun Di: Conceptualization, Writing – review & editing, Investigation. Xu Qian: Resources. Mengxia Ji: Resources. Ziqi Tian: Resources. Liqun Ye: Resources. Junze Zhao: Resources. Sheng Yin: Resources. Huaming Li: Resources, Funding acquisition. Jiexiang Xia: Conceptualization, Supervision, Funding acquisition.
